DataElement.preferredName: Tissue Donor Central Venous Access Catheter Anatomic Site Name
DataElement.preferredDefinition: A description of the location on or within the human body of the central line placement.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Tissue Donor Central Venous Access Catheter Anatomic Site
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Someone who gives blood or tissue or an organ to be used in another person._A tube surgically placed into a blood vessel for the purpose of giving intravenous fluid and drugs. It also can be used to obtain blood samples. This device avoids the need for separate needle insertions for each infusion or blood test. Examples of these devices include Hickman catheters, which require clamps to make sure the valve is closed, and Groshong catheters, which have a valve that opens as fluid is withdrawn or infused and remains closed when not in use._Named locations of, or within, the body.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Someone who gives blood or tissue or an organ to be used in another person.

Concepts.definition: Someone who gives blood or tissue or an organ to be used in another person.

Property.preferredName: Central Venous Access Catheter Anatomic Site
Property.preferredDefinition: A tube surgically placed into a blood vessel for the purpose of giving intravenous fluid and drugs. It also can be used to obtain blood samples. This device avoids the need for separate needle insertions for each infusion or blood test. Examples of these devices include Hickman catheters, which require clamps to make sure the valve is closed, and Groshong catheters, which have a valve that opens as fluid is withdrawn or infused and remains closed when not in use.:Named locations of, or within, the body.

Concepts.definition: A venous catheter positioned with the tip in the proximal third of the superior vena cava, the right atrium, or the inferior vena cava.
Named locations of or within the body.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.

ValueDomain.preferredName: Central Venous Access Catheter Anatomic Site Name
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A tube surgically placed into a blood vessel for the purpose of giving intravenous fluid and drugs or for obtaining blood samples._Named locations of or within the body._The words or language units by which a thing is known.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not otherwise specified.: Named locations of, or within, the body.

Concepts.definition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.
Named locations of or within the body.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A vein that starts within the inguinal region and extends to the lower extremities.

Concepts.definition: A vein that starts within the inguinal region and extends to the lower extremities.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The continuation of the axillary vein which follows the subclavian artery and then joins the internal jugular vein to form the brachiocephalic vein.

Concepts.definition: The vein that drains the axillary vein and joins the internal jugular vein to form the brachiocephalic vein. The subclavian vein runs parallel to the subclavian artery.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A continuation of the sigmoid sinus of the dura mater; joins the subclavian vein to form the brachiocephalic vein.

Concepts.definition: A continuation of the sigmoid sinus of the dura mater; joins the subclavian vein to form the brachiocephalic vein.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.

RepresentationTerm.preferredName: Central Venous Access Catheter Anatomic Site Name
RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A tube surgically placed into a blood vessel for the purpose of giving intravenous fluid and drugs. It also can be used to obtain blood samples. This device avoids the need for separate needle insertions for each infusion or blood test. Examples of these devices include Hickman catheters, which require clamps to make sure the valve is closed, and Groshong catheters, which have a valve that opens as fluid is withdrawn or infused and remains closed when not in use.:Named locations of, or within, the body.:The words or language units by which a thing is known.

Concepts.definition: A venous catheter positioned with the tip in the proximal third of the superior vena cava, the right atrium, or the inferior vena cava.
Named locations of or within the body.
The words or language units by which a thing is known.
